In addition, the task contrasts reflect self-referential episodic retrieval (self vs other recollection) rather than a clear affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/contrast requirement.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level analysis in healthy adults, the task probes self-referential episodic retrieval (self vs other, conceptual vs agentic recollection) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, cooperation, loved‑one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the affiliation_attachment category.

Although this is a whole-brain group analysis in (presumably) healthy adults, the contrast indexes episodic retrieval mode common across tasks/items (self-referential recollection paradigms) rather than a Social Communication contrast. The analysis does not measure exchange/processing of communicative signals (e.g., self vs other communicative targets or loved-one vs stranger) and therefore does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

Excluded: this is an ROI-based analysis (labelled "Medial PFC ROI") rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task map. Additionally, the reported contrast reflects episodic/self-referential retrieval mode rather than a clear Perception/Understanding-of-Others task contrast. ROI and non–whole-brain analyses meet the exclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level contrast on healthy adults (old > new), the contrast indexes episodic memory/retrieval (old vs new items) across self/other tasks rather than a measure of affiliation or attachment. It does not compare loved/close vs stranger or otherwise target social bonding/attachment, so it fails the task/contrast inclusion criteria for 'affiliation_attachment'.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the reported map indexes a general episodic retrieval mode common across retrieval tasks (including self and other) and old/new status. It is not a self-specific or self>other contrast measuring perception/understanding of the self, so it does not meet the requirement that the analysis directly probes self-related perception/knowledge.

The contrast is Old > New (episodic memory retrieval) collapsed across retrieval tasks and memory status; it indexes memory-related activation/ retrieval mode rather than a social-communication process. Although the overall study manipulates self vs other, this specific whole-brain contrast does not measure social communication (e.g., no social vs non-social or interpersonal contrast), so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This contrast reflects a general episodic retrieval-mode (common across retrieval tasks and old/new status) rather than a condition that specifically measures perception/understanding of others (e.g., Other vs Loved/Stranger). Although the study included self/other tasks, this conjunction does not isolate ‘other’ processing and thus does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Perception and Understanding of Others.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the Old > New contrast indexes episodic retrieval (memory strength/oldness) collapsed across retrieval tasks and item status, not Perception/Understanding of Others. It does not isolate other-related processing (e.g., Other vs Loved/Stranger) and therefore does not meet the task/contrast requirement for the perception_others annotation.

The contrast (New > Old) indexes episodic memory/encoding effects common across retrieval tasks (old vs new items), not a social-communication comparison. Although the study involves self/other recollection, this specific whole-brain contrast does not measure social communication (e.g., self vs other or loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast is Old > New (memory status) pooled across retrieval tasks and does not isolate self-related processing (e.g., self vs other or self-knowledge judgments). Although the study involves self-referential tasks, this specific whole-brain contrast indexes episodic memory (old/new) rather than Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and reports a whole-brain New>Old contrast, the task probes self-referential episodic recollection (self vs other, conceptual/agentic self) and incidental encoding — not affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). The contrast does not measure affiliation or attachment, so it fails the task/content inclusion criterion.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy controls, the task/contrast probes threat-related gaze processing (averted vs direct fearful gaze), not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' annotation.

Although the study used self-referential tasks and the map is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, the reported contrast (New > Old across tasks) indexes item memory/encoding effects rather than processes of perceiving or understanding the self (it does not isolate self vs other or self-related judgments). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a within-group, univariate whole-brain contrast in the healthy control (CON) group (AVERTED>DIRECT gaze). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

The New > Old contrast reflects novelty/encoding-related activity collapsed across retrieval tasks and memory status, not a comparison that isolates perception or understanding of others. Although the experiment included self/other conditions, this analysis is a general memory (new vs old) whole-brain effect rather than a social (other vs self or other vs baseline) contrast required for the perception_others category.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy control adults (CON) and thus meets the sample and analysis-type criteria, the contrast (AVERTED>DIRECT gaze for fearful faces) indexes perception of others' social cues/threat rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" domain.

This is a group-level, within-group univariate whole-brain contrast (AVERTED>DIRECT) reported for the control (CON) group of healthy adults, measuring perception of social cues (gaze/fear) about others. Although this is a within-group contrast in healthy controls (CON), the task contrasts fearful faces with direct vs averted gaze probing threat/attention/emotion processing, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

The DIRECT>AVERTED contrast tests perception of others' gaze/threat cues (fearful faces with direct vs averted gaze), not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it is a within-group control contrast (healthy adults) and likely whole-brain, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-control (CON) contrast comparing direct versus averted gaze (DIRECT>AVERTED) in healthy adults, which indexes eye contact / facial communication (a Social Communication subconstruct). It is a within-group univariate task contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria despite the reported null effect.

The contrast is a within-group analysis in an ASD (clinical) sample, not a healthy/control adult sample. Inclusion requires whole-brain group maps from healthy adults; because this is from a clinical group it must be excluded. (Although the table caption mentions controls, the provided analysis name/description specifies ASD and per instructions that takes precedence.)

This is a within-group contrast (DIRECT>AVERTED) reported for the control (CON) group of healthy adults probing perception of others' social cues (gaze/fear), not a between-group comparison, ROI, or connectivity analysis. Although the table notes a null result (no increased activation), it is a group-level task-evoked contrast relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others and thus meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (averted > direct fearful gaze) probes social threat/attention to gaze, not affiliation or attachment. In addition, the analysis is from a clinical ASD study (and/or contrasts reported for ASD group), not solely a healthy adult sample. Therefore it fails the task-domain and sample inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a within-group analysis in an ASD (clinical) sample rather than healthy adult participants. Inclusion requires whole-brain maps from healthy/control adults, so this analysis should be excluded.

The contrast is a within-group analysis in an ASD (clinical) sample (description: 'Within-group contrasts in ASD'), not a healthy adult/control group as required. In addition, the task contrasts (averted vs direct fearful gaze) probe perception of others' social cues (threat/gaze) rather than Perception and Understanding of the Self. This contrast (DIRECT > AVERTED) indexes responses to fearful faces and gaze direction (threat/attention processing), not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). In addition, the analysis is from a clinical ASD study (within-group contrasts reported for patient/control groups), so it does not meet the requirement of a group-level whole-brain map specifically reflecting healthy adults on an affiliation/attachment task.

The contrast (DIRECT>AVERTED) indexes reception of facial communication (gaze) and would meet the task/content requirement, but the analysis is reported as a within-group contrast in ASD (clinical group). The DIRECT>AVERTED contrast probes perception of others' gaze/threat cues (social perception), not self-related processing. The contrast reflects a within-group analysis in an ASD (clinical) sample (DIRECT > AVERTED in ASD). Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy/control adults only. This is a between-group contrast (CON > ASD for AVERTED>DIRECT). Inclusion requires a whole-brain group-level map from healthy adults alone (within-group/control group), and between-group contrasts (patient vs control) are explicitly excluded, so it does not meet the criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (CON > ASD for AVERTED>DIRECT), comparing healthy controls to a clinical group (ASD). Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone (within-group), and the exclusion criteria explicitly prohibit between-group contrasts (patient vs control). Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (controls > ASD) comparing AVERTED>DIRECT gaze. Inclusion requires analyses from healthy adults alone (within-group whole-brain maps) and excludes between-group or patient vs control contrasts. Exclude — this is a between-group contrast (CON > ASD), which violates the inclusion rule requiring analyses from healthy adults alone and the exclusion rule disallowing between-group contrasts. Additionally, the task contrasts fearful averted vs direct gaze (threat/social cue processing), not an affiliation/attachment task.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task probes attentional orienting to gaze/arrow cues and contextual congruence, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

The contrast (incongruent > congruent) indexes attentional orienting and contextual processing of gaze/arrow cues, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. The contrast indexes attentional orienting / contextual processing (incongruent > congruent) using gaze/arrow cues, not a task probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). In addition, the analysis is labeled as a small-volume correction (ROI/SVC) rather than a whole‑brain, task-evoked map. Therefore it does not meet the affiliation_attachment inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult, group-level whole-brain contrast (exploratory whole-brain analysis). The task used gaze cues (social attention) to probe contextual modulation of attentional orienting; perception of others' gaze/attentional direction falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action/attention perception). Although the contrast is incongruent>congruent (contextual effect) and may include non-social arrow cues, the paradigm explicitly targets social gaze processing and so meets the construct criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (incongruent > congruent) from an fMRI task that explicitly uses gaze cues (a social communicative signal) to probe attentional orienting. The sample is healthy adults and the analysis is neither an ROI nor a connectivity or between-group contrast. Because the task probes gaze-based orienting (gaze following is a form of social communication), the contrast is appropriate for the social_communication annotation.

The contrast (incongruent > congruent) probes contextual modulation of attentional orienting, not perception/understanding of the self. In addition, the result is reported as a small-volume correction (ROI/SVC), which is excluded by the criteria. Therefore it should not be included under "perception_self."

The contrast is a whole-brain group-level map of attentional orienting (incongruent vs congruent cues) using gaze/arrow cues and contextual congruence, not a task probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although the sample and analysis type meet other criteria, the task/contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.

This analysis used small-volume corrections (an ROI-restricted approach), which falls under the exclusion criterion for ROI analyses. In addition, the contrast (incongruent > congruent) indexes attentional/contextual processing rather than a clear social-communication contrast (and it pooled gaze and arrow cues rather than isolating a social-communication condition).

This contrast indexes attentional orienting and contextual (cue-target) congruency effects (incongruent > congruent), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge or agency. Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (incongruent > congruent) from a healthy adult sample examining attentional orienting by gaze cues. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or a between-group patient vs control contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

Although the task involves processing gaze (a social cue) and thus relates to perception of others, this specific analysis is a 'small-volume corrections' result (i.e., SVC/ROI-based). The inclusion criteria require group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps; ROI/SVC analyses are excluded, so this should not be included.

The contrast tests attentional orienting (gaze/arrow cue congruency) not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). This contrast indexes contextual modulation of attentional orienting by gaze/arrow cues (incongruent > congruent), not processes of self‑perception, self‑knowledge or agency. It therefore does not meet the content requirement for the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Self construct. (As an aside, the use of small‑volume correction also suggests regionally restricted inference rather than a whole‑brain group map.)

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults (incongruent>congruent) from an attentional orienting task that explicitly uses gaze cues (assessment of another person’s direction of attention). Gaze cueing is a Perception/Understanding of Others measure (perception of others’ attention/intent), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast "Main Effect of Healthiness" pertains to the healthiness attribute in food choices (dietary domain), not measures of affiliation/attachment or social bonding. The reported analysis is a "Small-volume corrections" analysis, i.e. an ROI-targeted/small-volume–corrected result rather than a whole‑brain, group‑level voxelwise map. The analysis is a small-volume correction (ROI) analysis rather than a whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise result. Therefore it does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement for the perception_others annotation.

This analysis ('Main Effect of Healthiness') indexes a dietary attribute (healthiness) in food choices, not a social-communication process. Although the paper also examines altruistic choice, this specific contrast measures food-related health attributes rather than receptive or productive social communication (e.g., kinship, cooperation, social comparison). Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication task/contrast inclusion criteria.

This analysis (Main Effect of Tastiness) probes food-related tastiness attributes in dietary choices, not measures of affiliation/attachment or social bonding. It does not assess attachment-related task contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger), so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast 'Main Effect of Healthiness' indexes a food attribute (healthiness) within dietary choices, not perception or understanding of other people. Although the study also examined altruistic choices, this specific analysis does not measure representations of others' mental states/traits or social scenarios, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

The contrast is the "Main Effect of Tastiness," a food-related attribute (tastiness) from a study of dietary and altruistic choices. This does not measure social communication (receptive or productive facial/non-facial communication) or a social-communication contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger). Although the study also examines altruistic/prosocial attributes, this specific analysis is non-social, so it fails the domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast ('Main Effect of Healthiness') indexes neural representations of a food attribute (healthiness) during food/altruistic choices, i.e., stimulus attribute/value coding, not processes of self-perception, self‑knowledge, or agency. It therefore does not measure "Perception and Understanding of Self" as defined and should be excluded.

This contrast (Main Effect of Tastiness) indexes neural encoding of a food attribute (tastiness) during valuation/choice, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. It therefore does not meet the content requirement for the "perception_self" construct.

The contrast is the Main Effect of Tastiness (a food attribute) from food/altruistic choice tasks. This analysis probes neural representations of attribute values in food and altruistic (prosocial) choices — a decision/value study — not a task of social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals). This analysis comes from a study of dietary and altruistic choice using multivariate decoding of attribute representations (domain-general vs domain-specific). Although the study includes altruistic choices in healthy adults and uses whole-brain contrasts, this specific analysis ('Main Effect of $Self *') indexes self-related value (self monetary amount) rather than perception/understanding of others. This is a group-level, whole-brain main effect mapping neural encoding of the 'Self' attribute (trial-wise self-related value) during choices. The contrast “Main Effect of $Other” indexes neural coding of value to another person (prosocial/other-focused attribute) during altruistic choices, not processes of self-awareness, self-monitoring, or self-knowledge. This contrast indexes prosocial/altruistic choice (an "Other" value attribute) rather than measures of social communication per the annotation definition (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals). The contrast is a group-level, task-evoked map indexing the trial-wise value to the Other during altruistic choices (a cooperation/prosocial task). This analysis indexes the neural encoding of a fairness attribute during altruistic/food choice (value/attribute representation), not a task or contrast assessing social communication (receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication, or explicit communication exchanges). This analysis appears to be a multivariate "neural prediction"/decoding of trial-wise attribute values (fairness) rather than a group-level univariate, voxelwise task contrast. The contrast (“Main Effect of Fairness”) indexes neural encoding of a social attribute (fairness) during food/altruistic choices (attribute/value representation), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. The contrast (“Main Effect of $Other”) comes from an altruistic-choice task in a healthy adult sample and reflects a group-level task-evoked main effect related to attributes concerning another person. The contrast is a group-level, within-subject main effect of a prosocial attribute (‘fairness’) from an altruistic choice task — a task probing perception/assessment of others (prosocial/fairness judgments). Insufficient evidence that this is a group-level, univariate whole-brain contrast indexing affiliation/attachment. The contrast (HC > (NC, TC)) comes from a study of attribute/value representations in food and altruistic choices (decision/value encoding), not an explicit task or contrast probing self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. The contrast comes from a study of value-based food and altruistic choice (decision-making/prosocial valuation), not a task measuring social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals). This contrast comes from a paper on dietary and altruistic choice and appears to reflect trial-wise attribute/value prediction (likely multivariate decoding) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain task map measuring affiliation/attachment. This contrast appears to index neural representations of choice-related attribute values (food and altruistic choices) rather than an explicit Perception/Understanding of Others task contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition). This contrast concerns neural value/attribute representations during food and altruistic choice (decision-making/prosocial valuation), not measures of social communication (receptive or productive facial or non‑facial communication). The contrast label ("HC > NC") and table caption pertain to attribute/value representations in food and altruistic choices and the paper emphasizes multivariate decoding and regulatory effects, not a clear task probing Perception/Understanding of Others. This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. The HC > TC contrast reflects differences in attribute/value-based choices (e.g., healthy vs tempting/tasty choices) in food/altruistic decision tasks, not tasks probing self-perception or self-knowledge. The contrast label (HC > TC) and table caption refer to attribute/value representations in food and altruistic choices, not an explicit Perception/Understanding of Others contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation). The contrast indexes attribute representations in food and altruistic choice conditions, not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. This contrast comes from a value/choice study (dietary and altruistic decisions) about attribute representations and regulation, not a task probing social communication (receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication).
