Although the metric is inter-subject correlation, the reported results are voxelwise t-maps of a task-evoked between-condition contrast (not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or resting-state analysis), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise comparison in healthy adult participants of a kinship/organ-donation movie paradigm (genetic vs. non-genetic sisters), which directly probes affiliation/attachment (kinship). Although they used inter-subject correlation (synchrony) rather than simple activation amplitude, the result is a group-level task-evoked, voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) and does not fall under ROI, seed-based/effective connectivity, resting-state, or patient-vs-control exclusions.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise comparison (clusters with peak coordinates and t-values) of inter-subject correlation between conditions where kinship was manipulated (genetic vs non-genetic sisters) in healthy adult subjects. The task is a kinship-related social scenario probing perception/understanding of others. It is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or patient vs control analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is from an emotional prosody comprehension task (simple/complex emotion vs neutral), not a task or contrast specifically measuring affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a healthy group whole‑brain contrast, it does not meet the task/content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

This is a within-group, voxelwise contrast (emotional prosody > neutral) reporting whole-brain corrected activations from an fMRI task that probes emotional prosody comprehension (receptive non-facial social communication). Nothing indicates a clinical/special sample or an ROI/ connectivity analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

The contrast indexes emotional prosody comprehension (perception of others' emotions) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although the sample and whole-brain contrast meet other criteria, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The analysis contrasts whole-brain voxelwise inter-subject correlation maps between two movie-viewing conditions (believed genetic vs adopted sisters) in a healthy adult sample. The task is a kinship-related social scenario (fits the "Kinship-related social scenarios" example) and the table reports group-level voxelwise clusters/t-values (not ROI, seed-based, resting-state, or between-group patient/control contrasts). Although ISC is not a classical GLM, it yields a voxelwise group statistical map of task-evoked responses, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a contrast of complex vs. simple emotional prosody (emotion recognition), not a task or contrast targeting affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, close-relationship or attachment measures). Although it is whole-brain and likely in healthy adults, it does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (emotion > neutral) in an emotional prosody task assessing perception of others' emotional states in a healthy adult sample, so it meets the sample, whole-brain, task, and contrast inclusion criteria and does not fall under any exclusion criteria.

This contrast probes emotional prosody comprehension (processing others' emotions; complex vs simple emotion) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody) reported at whole-brain corrected thresholds in a study of emotional prosody comprehension in healthy adults. Emotional prosody is reception of non-facial social communication, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotion) from an emotional prosody task probing others' emotional states in healthy adults. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes emotional prosody (complex vs simple emotion) rather than affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole‑brain healthy group contrast, the task does not measure affiliation or attachment and thus fails the domain inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, voxelwise contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody, pitch-controlled) reporting whole-brain MNI coordinates in a study of healthy adults. It probes reception of non-facial social communication (emotional prosody/affect recognition), is not ROI or connectivity-based, and is not a between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for 'social_communication'.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody, controlled for pitch) indexing perception/understanding of others' emotional states (emotional prosody). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and corresponds to healthy adult task activation, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes emotional prosody comprehension (complex vs simple emotions) — perception of others' emotional states — not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it appears to be a whole-brain, task-evoked group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

Although this is a healthy, group-level whole-brain task contrast (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target), the contrast indexes social approach/interaction (animate vs inanimate) rather than the exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior defined under the "social_communication" construct (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communication). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the social_communication label.

The contrast compares anticipation of an animate versus inanimate target (social/animate perception) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts anticipation of an animate versus inanimate target (social animacy/approach) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). The contrast taps animacy/social perception, not attachment/affiliation per the annotation definition, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (anticipation of animate target vs inanimate target) in healthy adult participants, probing animacy/social perception (anticipation of touching a human vs mannequin). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts anticipation of touching an animate versus inanimate target (general social/animate processing) rather than a direct measure of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the criterion that the task specifically measures affiliation/attachment.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (anticipation of touching an animate target vs baseline) indexes social/animate perception and approach rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Inclusion of a narcissistic-trait covariate (PNI‑NG) does not make the task a measure of Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrast (anticipation of an animate vs baseline) in healthy adult volunteers, probing animacy/social perception (anticipating touching a human hand). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adults (anticipation of touching an animate [human] target vs baseline) and therefore meets the whole-brain and sample criteria. The task probes anticipation of social/animate touch (approach to a human hand), which falls under non-facial social communication/production. The analysis is not an ROI, seed-based, resting-state, or between-group comparison (the PNI-NG is a covariate), so it meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast does not index affiliation/attachment (it contrasts anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target rather than measures of bonding/close relationships) and the reported analysis is a conjunction that includes a resting‑state metric (PLE), which falls under excluded resting‑state analyses. Although conducted in healthy adults and reported whole‑brain, it fails the task/content and resting‑state inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis is a conjunction of a task contrast with a resting-state PLE map (both with a narcissism covariate). Inclusion requires a standalone whole-brain, task-evoked group univariate map in healthy adults; resting-state/PLE analyses (and conjunctions that incorporate them) are explicitly excluded. Additionally, the contrast probes anticipation of an animate target (social processing) rather than a clear self-perception/self-knowledge task.

Although the task contrast (anticipation of an animate vs inanimate target) probes animacy perception and is whole-brain, this specific analysis is a conjunction that includes a resting-state measure (PLE) / resting-state vs baseline component. The exclusion criteria disallow resting-state analyses or analyses that are not purely task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise contrasts, so this analysis should be excluded.

Although the task (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target) involves social behavior, this specific analysis is a conjunction that includes resting-state PLE (a resting‑state metric). The inclusion rules require a group-level, whole‑brain task‑evoked map; resting‑state analyses (e.g., PLE) are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

Although this is a group-level fMRI contrast in healthy adults (likely whole-brain), the task contrasts facing-toward vs facing-away biological motion (FT > FA) which indexes stimulus direction/social involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

Although the contrast (facing-towards vs facing-away PLDs/HLs) is a whole-brain group fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the task measures perception of others' direction/social involvement rather than judgments about the self (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge). Therefore it does not meet the annotation requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

FT > FA contrasts participants' perception of whether biological motion stimuli are facing toward vs away (social orientation/potential for social involvement), which taps receptive non‑facial social communication. The study used healthy adult participants and reports a group-level whole‑brain task contrast (not ROI or connectivity), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

FT > FA is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing stimuli facing toward vs away (perception of others' direction/intent), from a healthy adult fMRI study probing mirror/mentalizing systems. It is a whole-brain univariate task contrast relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action perception), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast (FA > FT) comes from a task asking whether point-light displays/human-like walkers face toward or away — a perceptual/social-direction judgment — not a measure of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Although the sample and contrast appear to be whole-brain in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not index affiliation or attachment processes, so it fails the inclusion criterion.

FA>FT is a within-group task contrast (facing-away vs facing-toward) probing perception of biological/social motion (action/animacy perception) in healthy adults. It is a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group comparison), so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The FA>FT contrast indexes perception of biological motion/body orientation (facing toward vs away) which taps reception of socially relevant cues (potential for social involvement) — i.e., reception of non-facial social communication. The study reports a group-level fMRI task contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison) in healthy adults, so it meets the inclusion criteria for the "social_communication" annotation.

Although the sample and contrast are likely whole-brain healthy-group task data, the HL > PLD contrast reflects perceptual/biological-motion and social-direction processing (human-like walker vs point-light display), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment task/contrast requirement.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (HL > PLD) in healthy adult participants assessing perception of human-like motion and inferred social involvement (direction/facing judgments). The task indexes reception of non-facial social communication (inferring social meaning from body/biological motion), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast (HL > PLD) compares responses to human-like walkers versus point-light displays during judgments about stimulus direction (facing toward/away). Although it is a whole-brain, within-group task contrast in healthy adults, the task probes perception of others' biological motion/social potential, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' criterion.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level contrast in healthy adults, the FA>FT (facing away vs facing toward) contrast indexes perception of stimulus direction/social involvement relative to the observer, not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or agency. It therefore does not meet the construct definition for Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (HL > PLD) from healthy adult participants comparing human-like walkers to point-light displays during a direction-judgment task. It indexes perception/understanding of others (animacy/action perception) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group-level contrast on healthy adults, the task contrasts point-light displays versus human-like walkers and a direction judgement (facing toward/away). This measures biological motion and social involvement potential, not affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content criterion for the affiliation_attachment category.

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast (PLD > HL) comparing types of biological/social motion stimuli in healthy adult participants. It probes action/animacy perception (Perception and Understanding of Others subconstructs), is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

The PLD > HL contrast compares stimulus types (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) in a biological-motion/direction judgment task. Although it involves social perception, it does not probe self-related processes (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge) nor a self vs other comparison, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

The contrast (STIMULUS*DIRECTION) indexes perceptual coding of stimulus type and facing direction (social involvement potential) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a group-level whole-brain task contrast on healthy adults, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it fails the task inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast in healthy adults comparing perception of point-light displays (PLD) versus human-like walkers while judging facing direction. The task probes perception of non‑facial social signals / social intentions from body motion (reception of non‑facial communication), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast).

The contrast tests participants' judgments of facing direction for biological motion (point-light and human-like walkers), a within-subject, group-level fMRI task that probes reception of socially relevant, non-facial communicative cues (body/biological motion conveying social intention). This meets the sample (healthy adults), whole-brain univariate task-evoked map, and Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication) inclusion criteria and does not fall under the exclusions (ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical contrasts).

This is a within-subject fMRI task contrast (STIMULUS*DIRECTION) from healthy participants probing perception of others (PLD vs human-like walkers facing toward/away), fitting the Perception/Understanding of Others construct. It is a group-level task-evoked voxelwise contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (judging whether point-light displays / walkers face toward or away from the observer) probes perception of others' motion and potential for social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or explicit self-related judgments. Although the sample and analysis appear to be group-level whole-brain in healthy adults, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

Although the analysis appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts PLD vs human-like walkers (and stimulus direction) probing social perception/possible social involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the content criterion for affiliation_attachment.

This contrast (HL > PLD; judging whether walkers face toward/away) probes biological-motion/stimulus-type and direction/perception, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it fails the primary inclusion criterion.

The contrast reflects a within-group task-based fMRI comparison in healthy adults probing perception of biological motion and the potential for social involvement (inferring facing direction/social intention from point-light displays vs human-like walkers). This targets reception of non‑facial social communication (inferring social meaning/intent) and is a standard group-level univariate task contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast FT_PLD > HL is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI comparison of two stimulus types (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) during a task judging facing direction, which probes action/animacy perception (a subcomponent of Perception and Understanding of Others). It is reported as a group-level fMRI contrast (not a ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (FT_PLD > HL) indexes perception of biological motion and stimulus-directed social involvement (PLD vs human-like walkers facing toward/away), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although the task references the observer (facing toward/away), it does not measure judgments about the self or self-related traits/states required by the 'perception_self' construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group task contrast (HL > PLD) from a healthy adult fMRI study probing perception of social intent/facing direction (inferring social meaning from biological motion), which falls under reception of non‑facial social communication. The contrast appears to be a standard univariate group-level comparison (not ROI or connectivity) and therefore meets the inclusion criteria. (If this specific row were an ROI or non–whole-brain analysis or from a clinical subgroup, it should be excluded.)

This is a within-group task contrast from a healthy adult sample comparing human-like walkers (HL) versus point-light displays (PLD) during a social perception task (judging facing direction). It reflects perception/action/animacy processing of others, is not a between-group, ROI, or connectivity analysis, and therefore meets the whole-brain univariate task-evoked inclusion criteria described.

Although this is a group-level fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the task (judging stimulus direction of point-light displays vs human-like walkers) probes basic biological-motion/social-perceptual processing (potential for social involvement) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast index affiliation and attachment.

Although the study used healthy adults and likely reports group-level whole-brain contrasts, the FT_HL > PLD contrast compares stimulus types (human-like walker vs point-light display) related to social/perceptual processing of others' motion. It does not directly index processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about the self, so it does not meet the construct requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The contrast is a group-level, task-evoked univariate comparison in healthy adults (PLD vs HL) probing perception of social orientation/intent from biological motion (facing toward/away), which falls under reception of non-facial social communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (PLD vs HL; facing-away condition) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological/social motion (action/animacy perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and thus meets the whole-brain Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.

Although the study uses healthy adult participants and presents a whole-brain task contrast, the task (judging whether point-light displays or human-like walkers face toward/away from the observer) probes biological motion and potential social involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the domain requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" annotation.

The contrast FA_PLD > HL compares stimulus types (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) in a task about perceiving others' motion/direction. Although the task involves judging whether stimuli face the observer, the analysis targets processing of others' biological motion and stimulus type, not self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Therefore it does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ construct requirements.

This is a within-group, task-evoked group contrast in healthy adults comparing human-like walkers (HL) to point-light displays (PLD). The task probes perception of biological motion and social intention/potential for social involvement (receptive non-facial social communication), so it meets the Social Communication construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast compares stimulus types (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) and direction coding of biological motion / social involvement potential, not processes of self-awareness, self-judgment, agency, or self-knowledge. Although the sample and likely whole-brain group analysis meet other criteria, the contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self as defined by the annotation.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing human-like walkers (HL) to point-light displays (PLD) in a healthy adult sample assessing perception of biological motion/social intention. It reflects perception/understanding of others (action/animacy perception), and is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (PLD_FT > FA; judging point-light displays/human walkers facing toward vs away) probes perceptual coding of biological motion and potential for social involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain, healthy-group task contrast, it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

This is a within-subject, post-hoc fMRI contrast (PLD_FT > FA) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological/social motion (point-light displays facing toward vs away). It reflects a task-evoked, group-level contrast indexing perception/understanding of others (action/animacy perception), and is not described as an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast (PLD_FA > FT) tests perceptual coding of biological motion / stimulus direction (point-light displays facing away vs toward) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a group whole-brain fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the task does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs required by the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (PLD facing-toward > facing-away) probes perception of others' biological motion/social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although likely a healthy-group fMRI contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self (it is about others' directionality), so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adults (PLD facing-toward > facing-away) that indexes perception of body orientation/social involvement — a form of reception of non-facial social communication. It is not a between-group, ROI, or connectivity analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (PLD facing toward/away) in a healthy adult sample probing perception of social intent/body orientation (reception of non-facial social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (PLD facing away vs facing toward) indexes perception of others' motion/orientation and potential for social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about the self. Therefore it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" construct.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (PLD facing-away vs facing-toward) in healthy adults probing perception of biological/social motion (point-light displays), which maps onto the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (animacy/action perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (HL_FT > FA) stems from a task about perceiving biological motion / stimulus direction (human-like walkers facing towards vs away), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, bonding). Although the study likely used healthy adults and a group fMRI contrast, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

HL_FT > FA appears to be a within-subject, group-level contrast (human-like walkers facing toward > facing away) from a task where healthy adult participants judged biological motion/agent direction. This is a whole-brain univariate task contrast tapping animacy/action perception (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast (human-like walkers facing towards vs away from the observer) involves judgments relative to the observer, the task probes perception of stimulus direction/social involvement rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the participant's own traits/states. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct and should be excluded.

The contrast (HL_FT > FA: human-like walkers facing toward vs away) is a task-based, group-level univariate fMRI contrast probing perception of social approach/orientation (reception of non-facial social communication/body/gaze cues). The study involves healthy adults and the reported analysis is not described as an ROI or connectivity analysis, so it meets the whole-brain, task-evoked social communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast (HL facing away vs facing toward; biological motion/social direction) is a perceptual/social-cognitive task about motion and social orientation, not an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group fMRI contrast on healthy adults, it does not measure affiliation or attachment as defined by the inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares human-like walkers facing away vs toward the observer (HL_FA > FT) in healthy participants, indexing perception of body orientation/social involvement — a form of Reception of Non‑Facial Communication. The result appears to be from a group-level task-evoked univariate fMRI contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis), so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

HL_FA > FT is a within-group task contrast (human-like walkers facing away vs toward) probing perception of others (animacy/action/social direction). It is a univariate task-evoked fMRI contrast from the healthy sample in the study (not a between-group, ROI, or connectivity analysis), so it meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group-level task contrast in healthy adults, the task probes general social evaluative conflict (judging targets based on mixed trait information) rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

Although the contrast (HL_FA > FT) appears to be a whole-brain, group-level comparison in healthy adults and is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, the task contrasts the perceived direction/social involvement of observed agents (facing toward/away from the observer). This probes perception of others' orientation/social involvement rather than processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" construct and should be excluded.

Although the reported analysis is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast, the task probes social evaluations of other people (judgments of targets with conflicting trait information), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. The 'perception_self' construct requires measures of awareness/knowledge/judgments about the self (or closely related self-referential tasks), so this analysis does not meet the domain requirement.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked analysis (whole-brain MLM) conducted in a healthy adult sample, probing social evaluations of other people (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Although the analysis is whole-brain and likely from a healthy adult sample, the task probes social evaluation/decision-making about learned trait information (resolving evaluative conflict), not social communication per the annotation definition (exchange or reception/production of socially relevant signals such as facial/non‑facial communication, kinship/cooperation/competition scenarios). Therefore it does not meet the required Social Communication task domain.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map across ~1,000 studies rather than a single group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring a Social Communication task/contrast. It therefore does not meet the requirement for a univariate whole-brain group map specific to Social Communication in healthy adults.

This entry describes an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis across ~1,000 studies using the keyword “social,” not a single group-level, task-evoked whole-brain statistical map from a healthy adult sample measuring a Perception/Understanding-of-Others contrast. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement for a univariate whole-brain group map focused on perception/understanding of others.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis of studies containing the keyword "social" rather than a group-level task contrast specifically measuring affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship/cooperation tasks). Although it yields whole-brain maps, it is not a single-task, healthy adult univariate contrast targeting the affiliation/attachment construct, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a Neurosynth automated meta-analysis map derived from ~1,000 studies using the keyword 'social', not a single-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adults measuring perception/understanding of the self. It is neither specific to self-related tasks/contrasts nor limited to a healthy adult sample, and therefore does not meet the sample and whole-brain task-contrast inclusion criteria for the 'perception_self' annotation.

This analysis reflects a general 'social vs. non‑social' NeuroSynth meta‑analysis (and related ROI confirmation), not a task specifically probing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation). It is also a meta‑analytic/neurosynth map rather than a single group-level task contrast targeting affiliation, so it does not meet the task-specific and whole‑brain group contrast inclusion criteria.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map (aggregate of many studies) of “social” vs. non-social images rather than a single group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from a healthy adult sample. It therefore does not meet the requirement for a primary group-level whole‑brain contrast generalizable to healthy adults, and the contrast reflects broad social processing (not a clearly defined social-communication task/contrast).

This entry reports a NeuroSynth automated meta-analysis (and related ROI-driven follow-up), not a single-study, group-level whole-brain univariate task contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring Perception/Understanding of Self. It indexes general "social" activation across many studies (and the independent study used ROI extractions), so it does not meet the required whole-brain, self-related task contrast inclusion criteria.

This entry is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis (a meta-analytic map derived from ~1,000 studies), not a single-group, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast from a healthy adult sample. The inclusion criteria require a group-level voxelwise map generalizable to healthy adults from a primary study/task; a NeuroSynth meta-map does not meet that requirement, so it should be excluded.

Excluded because this is an ROI analysis (table reports ROI results) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map. In addition, the study examines face specialization/development rather than an affiliation/attachment task/contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

This is an ROI analysis (table lists ROIs and ROI results) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise univariate map, which violates the whole-brain requirement. In addition, the task concerns face specialization (not Perception/Understanding of the Self). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This entry reports ROI analyses (regions of interest) rather than a group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked map. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so it cannot be included even though the task (face processing) relates to perception of others.

This analysis reports ROI analyses (regions isolated from a subset of adults) rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked contrast. Even though the study concerns face processing (a form of facial communication), ROI analyses are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) from 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task that requires perceiving and tracking others' emotional states. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and directly measures perception/understanding of others, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate comparison (emotional > neutral video clips) in 34 healthy adults from an empathic-accuracy task that requires perceiving others' emotional states (receptive social communication / affect recognition). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults (meets sample and analysis requirements), the task and contrast (emotional > neutral video clips in an empathic accuracy task) probe perception/understanding of others' emotions (empathy), not perception or self-knowledge/agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task is an empathic accuracy task probing cognitive/affective empathy to autobiographical emotional videos—not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, parental/peer bonding). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assesses affiliation/attachment.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level healthy adult analysis, the task probes empathic tracking of emotional intensity in narrators rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved one vs stranger, parental/peer bonding). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain contrast (neutral > emotional) from 34 healthy adults performing an empathic-accuracy task that requires perceiving and tracking others' emotions (receptive social communication/non‑facial communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although the study used a healthy adult sample and reports whole-brain group contrasts, the contrast (neutral > emotional video clips) probes perception of others' emotional states (an empathic/other-focused task), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (neutral > emotional) from 34 healthy adults performing an empathic-accuracy task that requires perceiving and tracking others' emotional states. The task and contrast probe perception/understanding of others and meet the inclusion (healthy sample, whole-brain task-evoked map) and do not trigger any exclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not between-group).

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, group‑level correlation with empathic accuracy in healthy adults, the task probes empathic tracking of emotional intensity rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., close‑relationship, kinship, cooperation or attachment style measures). It does not target affiliation/attachment contrasts (such as loved‑one vs stranger) or attachment assessments, so it does not meet the "affiliation_attachment" inclusion criterion.

Healthy adult sample (N=34) and the reported results are whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked activations (TFCE pFWE<0.05). The contrast/analysis relates brain activity to empathic accuracy (Z-EA) during viewing/rating of autobiographical emotional videos, which indexes receptive social communication (perception/tracking of others' emotions). This is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analysis in healthy adult participants relating neural activation to empathic accuracy (Z‑EA) during an empathic accuracy task (tracking others' emotional states). The task and contrast probe understanding/perception of others' emotional states (fits the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct), and the analysis is not ROI-, connectivity-, or between-group based, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level, whole-brain task analysis in healthy adults, the contrast relates brain activity to empathic accuracy (Z-EA) — i.e., ability to track others' emotions. That indexes perception/understanding of others (empathy), not self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criterion.

This analysis comes from an empathic accuracy task (tracking narrator emotional intensity) and reports brain activity related to empathic accuracy (Z-EA). Although it is a whole‑brain, group‑level map from healthy adults, the task measures empathy/emotion tracking rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in 34 healthy adults relating brain activity during an empathic-accuracy task (rating others' emotional intensity) to Z-transformed empathic-accuracy scores. The task and contrast index understanding/perception of others' emotional states (Understanding Mental States), and the analysis is not ROI-, connectivity-, or between-group based.

This analysis indexes neural correlates of empathic accuracy (tracking others' emotional intensity) and reports voxels negatively related to Z-scored empathic-accuracy scores — i.e., perception of others, not processes of self-perception/self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group map, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it fails the construct inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in a sample of healthy adults relating brain activation during an empathic accuracy task (watching/autobiographical emotional video clips and rating narrators) to Z-transformed empathic-accuracy scores. The task measures reception of socially relevant information (emotional tracking from videos), is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and is not a between-group contrast — therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults, the contrast indexes tracking of a narrator's emotional intensity (an empathic accuracy/emotion-processing task). It does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved-one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation) or assess attachment-related constructs, so it does not meet the affiliation_attachment task criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate task analysis in healthy adults (n=34) correlating BOLD with participants' continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity while watching autobiographical video clips. The contrast indexes reception of socially relevant, non-facial communicative signals (emotion recognition/tracking), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in a healthy adult sample correlating BOLD with participants' ratings of another person's emotional intensity. It directly indexes perception/understanding of others' emotional states (understanding mental states) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes brain activity tracking perceived emotional intensity of others (empathic accuracy/response to emotional videos), i.e., perception of others' states, not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain group analysis in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self.

Although the analysis is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task measures empathic accuracy and moment-to-moment emotional intensity tracking for (likely stranger) autobiographical videos—not affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, bonding, kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, attachment style). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast index affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate map from 34 healthy adult participants relating BOLD to participants' continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity (a social perceptual/emotional-tracking task). That fits the Social Communication construct (reception of non-facial/social information). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This analysis indexes participants' tracking of another person's emotional intensity (empathic accuracy/response to others' emotions), not processes of self-perception, self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although the sample and analysis appear to meet the healthy adult and whole-brain criteria, the contrast measures perception of others rather than Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, voxelwise fMRI analysis in healthy adults correlating BOLD with participants' continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity — a direct measure of perceiving/assessing another's emotional state. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants investigating cooperation vs deception in a theory-of-mind/social interaction task. The task directly probes social communication (cooperation/deception), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study used a cooperation/deception ToM task in healthy adults with a group-level whole-brain contrast, the specific contrast DEC>COOP indexes greater activity for deception relative to cooperation (deceptive processing), not engagement related to affiliation/attachment per se. The inclusion criteria require the contrast to measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., cooperation > other or loved vs stranger); DEC>COOP does not meet that requirement.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants (n=13) probing theory-of-mind (understanding others' intentions) during cooperation vs deception. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a healthy-group, whole-brain task contrast (DEC>COOP), the task probes theory-of-mind about story characters (others' intentions/expectations: deception vs cooperation), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about one's own traits/states. Therefore it does not fit the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

The contrast DEC>COOPDEC is a within-group, voxelwise task-evoked contrast from healthy adult participants (n=13) probing cooperative vs deceptive social interactions. The task measures social communication (cooperation/deception reasoning about others' intentions), and this is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

DEC>COOPDEC is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults comparing deception versus cooperation/deception conditions in a theory-of-mind task (cartoons requiring reasoning about others' intentions). This directly probes Understanding Mental States and meets the sample and analysis inclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not between-group).

Although the study used a cooperation/deception ToM task in healthy adults with whole-brain voxelwise contrasts, this specific contrast (DEC > COOPDEC) isolates deception-related processing (mismatch of intentions) rather than affiliation/attachment per se. It does not directly measure affiliation (e.g., cooperation vs neutral or loved-one vs stranger), so it fails the requirement that the contrast index affiliation/attachment processes.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults comparing cooperative/deceptive interactions to deception alone. The task explicitly includes cooperation (an affiliation-related social interaction), and the COOPDEC>DEC contrast isolates the cooperative component, so it meets the affiliation/attachment task and analysis criteria.

Although the contrast is whole-brain and from healthy adults, the task probes theory-of-mind about protagonists' intentions (others) — deception versus cooperative/deceptive interactions — not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the participant's own states. The contrast does not target self-perception (no self vs other or self-evaluative contrast), so it fails the construct requirement for "Perception and Understanding of Self."

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from healthy adult participants, derived from a task probing cooperation/deception (social interaction, theory-of-mind). The task maps directly onto the Social Communication domain (cooperation/deception), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Healthy adult sample; contrast is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrast (ToM task) examining cooperation-related social interactions. The task assesses cooperation (an affiliation/attachment-relevant paradigm) and the contrast COOPDEC>COOP compares cooperative/deceptive social interaction to cooperation, not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC > DEC) from healthy adult participants on a theory-of-mind task assessing cooperative/deceptive social interactions. It directly measures perception and understanding of others (ToM) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast on healthy adults, the COOPDEC>DEC contrast reflects theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions (cooperation/deception vs deception) rather than processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or judgments about the self. Therefore it does not meet the “Perception and Understanding of Self” inclusion requirement.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants examining cooperation/deception in a social interaction (ToM) paradigm. The task maps onto the Social Communication construct (cooperation/deception), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants, probing theory-of-mind / understanding others' intentions in cooperative vs deceptive social interactions. It matches the Perception and Understanding of Others construct and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level whole-brain contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy volunteers using a task that explicitly manipulates cooperation versus deception. Cooperation is a prototypical affiliation-related condition, so the COOP>DEC contrast indexes affiliation/attachment processes and meets the inclusion criteria (not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast).

Healthy adult sample (healthy volunteers). The reported COOP>DEC contrast is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate comparison (table reports voxelwise thresholds). The task explicitly probes cooperation/deception (social interaction, intentions/expectations), which fits the Social Communication construct (cooperation). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults and involves social cooperative/deceptive scenarios, it indexes theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions/expectations (mentalizing about others), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about one's own states. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) from healthy volunteers performing a cooperation/deception ToM task. The task explicitly involves cooperation (an example Social Communication task), it is a univariate group-level contrast (not ROI or connectivity), and not a between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (COOP > COOPDEC) from healthy adult subjects, derived from a ToM paradigm that explicitly includes a cooperation condition (an affiliation-related construct). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy adult participants (n=13) derived from a theory-of-mind task (reasoning about others' intentions/expectations). The contrast measures Perception and Understanding of Others (understanding mental states) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a healthy, whole-brain, group-level task contrast, it indexes theory-of-mind reasoning about protagonists' intentions in cooperative versus deceptive social interactions (i.e., understanding others), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge or agency. Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) from healthy adult participants in a theory-of-mind task asking subjects to reason about others' intentions/expectations (cooperation vs cooperation/deception). It is a univariate task-evoked contrast measuring Perception and Understanding of Others, and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants examining responses to viewing eyes and dynamic pupillary signals — a form of receptive facial/social communication (eye contact/affective signaling). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for 'social_communication'.

Although the analysis is a group-level task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task probes pupillary mirroring and social salience of eye stimuli rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). It does not assess attachment/affiliation constructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although the task involves cooperation, the COOP>COOPDEC contrast probes theory-of-mind reasoning about protagonists' intentions (other-focused mentalizing: cooperation vs deceptive interactions), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or self-monitoring. Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain main effect (viewing others' eyes) in a healthy adult sample, probing perception of others' social signals (dynamic eye/pupil stimuli). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a region-of-interest analysis (not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map) and thus violates the whole-brain requirement. In addition, the task probes pupillary mirroring/social salience rather than a specific affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level result from healthy adults, the contrast (‘main effect of viewing eyes’) indexes perception of others' eye/pupil stimuli and social salience rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency or explicit self-monitoring. It therefore does not meet the task/content requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a region-of-interest analysis (not a group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task map). Although the task (viewing eyes/pupils) taps social facial communication, ROI analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

The analysis is a Region-of-Interest (ROI) analysis (analysis name: "Region of interest analysis"), which violates the inclusion requirement for group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps. Therefore it should be excluded despite involving social perception of others' eyes/pupils.

This is labeled a 'Region of interest analysis' (ROI). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, whole-brain univariate (voxelwise) task-evoked map. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. (Additionally, the task targets social salience of others' pupils rather than an explicit Perception/Understanding-of-Self contrast, but the ROI status is sufficient reason for exclusion.)

Although the analysis is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the task probes pupillary mirroring/social salience rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adults examining dynamic exchange of pupillary signals between viewer and observed (eye stimuli), which indexes nonverbal/social information transfer (receptive facial/eye communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although the task (viewing dynamic pupils/eyes) clearly probes social/facial communication in healthy adults, the specific analysis is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (per the analysis name). ROI analyses do not meet the requirement for group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked maps and are therefore excluded.

Exclude. The reported analysis is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (not a whole-brain, voxelwise group map) and the task probes pupillary coherence/social salience rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Both the ROI method and the lack of an affiliation/attachment task violate the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate main effect in healthy adult participants examining responses to viewing others' pupil changes (a social/perceptual cue about another's state). The contrast reflects perception of others' signals (social salience) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a region-of-interest analysis (explicitly labelled 'Region of interest analysis'), which violates the inclusion requirement for a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. Additionally, the task (viewing pupils/eyes) does not clearly target Perception and Understanding of Self; regardless, the ROI approach alone is sufficient reason for exclusion.

The contrast examines coherence/discordance between the subject's own pupil changes and observed pupils, i.e. monitoring one's internal autonomic state relative to another — a form of self-monitoring/self-perception. The study used healthy adult participants and reports group-level task-evoked whole-brain effects (main effects/contrasts), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the "perception_self" inclusion criteria.

The entry is an ROI analysis (labelled "Regions of interest") rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. The inclusion criteria require univariate, whole-brain, group-level maps; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

This is a region-of-interest analysis (table name: "Region of interest analysis"), which violates the exclusion criteria requiring whole-brain, voxelwise group-level univariate maps. Although the sample and task are appropriate, ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

The reported analysis is an ROI-based contrast (table titled 'Regions of interest') rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map, and the task contrasts (viewing dynamic pupils / social salience) do not target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it fails the whole-brain and task-domain inclusion criteria.

The analysis is labeled as a "Regions of interest" analysis (ROI), which violates the exclusion criterion requiring group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked maps. Although the sample is healthy adults, the ROI nature (not whole-brain) means it should be excluded from the perception_self annotation.

The analysis is labeled as "Regions of interest," indicating an ROI-based analysis rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrast. Although the task (viewing others' eyes/pupillary exchange) probes perception of others and the sample appears to be healthy adults, the exclusion criteria disallow ROI analyses. Therefore it does not meet the whole-brain inclusion requirement.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task manipulates pupillary coherence/salience (positive vs negative pupil correlation) rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). It probes social salience/attention rather than measures of affiliation or attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (positive > negative) compares within healthy adult participants how positively vs negatively correlated observed pupil changes modulate brain activity during viewing of eyes. This is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast (main effect of viewing eyes) addressing reception of nonverbal/eye-based social signals, so it fits the Social Communication construct (reception of facial/eye communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This analysis does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria. The task probes pupillary exchange and social salience, not affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or kinship/cooperation scenarios). Additionally the analysis is reported as a "Regions of interest" result (ROI), which is explicitly excluded by the rules. Therefore it should not be included.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (positive > negative) indexes coherence between observed and observed pupillary changes (social salience/eye processing), not an explicit measure of self-related cognition (self-knowledge, agency, self-monitoring or judgments about the self). Therefore it does not meet the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Self inclusion criteria.

The analysis is labeled 'Regions of interest', indicating an ROI-based analysis. Although the task (viewing eyes/pupillary exchange) taps facial/social communication and the sample is healthy adults, the inclusion criteria require group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

The contrast (positive > negative) indexes responses to others' dynamic pupil signals (social perceptual cues) during a task in healthy adults. It is reported as a group-level task-evoked fMRI contrast (whole-brain main effect of viewing eyes), not an ROI/seed or between-group analysis, and therefore fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (animacy/social cue perception).

The specific analysis is labeled as "Regions of interest," indicating an ROI-based analysis. The inclusion rules require group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise maps; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Although the task involves perceiving others' pupils (a social/perception paradigm) and the sample is healthy adults, the ROI nature disqualifies it.

Excluded — this is a group × gaze-direction interaction involving an ASC clinical group vs controls (a between-group contrast/interaction). Inclusion requires a within-group, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adults only; additionally the contrast addresses gaze perception/theory-of-mind rather than an explicit affiliation/attachment task.

This analysis is a Group × Gaze Direction interaction comparing controls and an autism spectrum condition (ASC) group. It therefore constitutes a between-group interaction (patient vs control) rather than a whole-brain univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample alone, which violates the sample and exclusion criteria.

This analysis appears to come from a "Regions of interest" table and reports the main effect of viewing eyes (social/perceptual processing of others' pupils). It is therefore an ROI-based/social-perception contrast rather than a group-level whole‑brain, voxelwise map targeting Perception/Understanding of the Self (self‑knowledge or agency). ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, and the contrast does not clearly index self‑related processing (self‑monitoring or self‑judgment).

This analysis reports a group (ASC vs control) × gaze-direction interaction and contrasts between clinical and control groups. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level univariate maps from healthy adults alone; exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/interactions. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a group × gaze-direction interaction (controls vs ASC), i.e. a between-group interaction rather than a group-level whole-brain map from a healthy/control sample alone. Between-group contrasts/interactions are explicitly excluded, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise contrast in the healthy control participants (Controls: direct > averted gaze), which probes facial social-communication (eye contact/gaze perception). It is not an ROI or connectivity or a between-group contrast, and the table reports whole-brain coordinates, so it meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

Although this is a within-group contrast from the healthy control participants (direct > averted gaze), the task probes perception of others' gaze/theory-of-mind, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

Although the contrast is reported for the healthy control group (controls: direct > averted), the task probes gaze perception and theory-of-mind in the context of autism, not explicit affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved‑one vs stranger). The contrast does not index an affiliation/attachment task as required, so it should be excluded.

The contrast is from the ASC (clinical) group (averted > direct) rather than a healthy/control sample. Inclusion requires group-level whole-brain maps from healthy adults generalizable to the healthy population. Because this analysis is from a clinical subgroup (autism spectrum), it does not meet the sample inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (controls: direct > averted gaze) from the healthy control participants, probing gaze perception/theory-of-mind (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is from the ASC (autism) group (averted > direct gaze), i.e. a clinical sample. Inclusion requires whole-brain, group-level maps from healthy/control adults. Because this is not a healthy control group (and the table also reports group × gaze interactions), the analysis does not meet the sample/whole-brain healthy-control inclusion criteria.

This contrast is from the ASC (autism) clinical group (averted > direct). Inclusion requires analyses on healthy adult participants generalizable to the healthy population. Because this is a clinical group contrast (not a healthy/control-only whole-brain map) it must be excluded.

This contrast is from the ASC (clinical) group (averted > direct) rather than a healthy control group, so it does not meet the requirement that analyses be on healthy adults and generalizable to the healthy population. Additionally, the contrast probes gaze/theory-of-mind processing of others (not Perception/Understanding of the Self), and the study centers on group comparisons/interactions which are excluded.

The contrast is from the ASD (clinical) group (EYES UP: ASD). Inclusion requires analyses on healthy adult participants only. Although the task taps facial/social processing, the sample is a clinical group so it should be excluded.

This analysis reports within-group contrasts from an ASD (clinical) sample attending to eyes vs mouth during face perception. The inclusion criteria require healthy adult (control) group whole-brain task maps and tasks probing Perception/Understanding of Self. This is a clinical group (ASD) and probes face-attention/perception rather than self-related processes, so it should be excluded.

This analysis is from an ASD clinical group (not a healthy adult sample) and the task probes face/configural processing and attention to eyes vs mouth rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a within‑group whole‑brain contrast, the sample and task do not meet the inclusion criteria for the affiliation_attachment annotation.

The contrast comes from a study of autism that reports within-group contrasts (attend-to-eyes vs mouth) likely for clinical (ASD) and/or control groups. Inclusion requires a whole-brain group-level map from healthy adult participants only (control group). The provided table caption/description does not specify that this map is from the healthy/control group alone, so it does not meet the sample criterion.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast from the healthy control group, the task (Thatcher illusion; attending to eyes vs mouth; grotesqueness/face configural processing) assesses perceptual/social attention/face processing rather than affiliation or attachment (relationships, bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, kinship, etc.). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a within-group, group-level contrast for the healthy control (CON) sample from a face-attention task (attend eyes vs mouth, upright/inverted). It targets facial/social communication (eye-region processing → reception of facial communication), and the table reports whole-brain within-group contrasts (FDR-corrected). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast from the healthy control group (so it meets sample and analysis-type requirements), the task probes face perception and social attention (attending to eyes vs mouth in Thatcherized faces) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This analysis is from the ASD (clinical) group rather than a healthy adult sample, and the task (Thatcher illusion; attending to eyes vs mouth/grotesqueness perception) does not operationalize affiliation/attachment. It therefore fails the sample and task inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast from the healthy control group (CON) contrasting attention to eyes vs mouth in faces. The task probes face/social perception (attention to eye-region and social/emotional face processing), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others, and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

The contrast is a within-group analysis of the ASD (clinical) sample ("MOUTH UP: ASD"), not a healthy/control-only group. This analysis reports an Age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction across adolescents and young adults (a between-group interaction) and the paper emphasizes ROI (ventral striatum) follow-up. Inclusion criteria require a group-level, whole-brain univariate map from a healthy adult sample generalizable to adults and exclude between‑group contrasts/interactions and ROI‑only results. Therefore it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. It involves a between-group interaction including adolescents and young adults (Age group × evaluative perspective × domain), so it is not a univariate whole-brain map from a healthy adult-only sample and includes a between-group contrast. The report also relies on ROI follow-ups in ventral striatum. Although the task taps social evaluation of others, the age-group interaction and ROI-based follow-ups exclude it from the 'perception_others' annotation.

This analysis reports a three-way Age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction that involves an age-group between-subject factor (adolescents vs young adults). Inclusion requires whole-brain group-level maps from healthy adult participants only and excludes between-group contrasts/interactions. Because this is a between-group interaction (and the sample includes adolescents), it does not meet the criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in a healthy adult sample, the task probes eye-gaze / social attention perception rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

The reported analysis is a three-way Age group × evaluative perspective × domain ANOVA that directly contrasts adolescents and young adults (a between-group interaction). Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adult participants only (no between-group comparisons). In addition, the paper reports follow-up ROI analyses. Because this is an age-group comparison (and not an adult-only whole-brain task contrast), it fails the inclusion criteria.

Healthy typical adult sample; group-level, voxelwise univariate map reporting correlations between AQ and the task contrast (variable vs constant eye gaze), which is a task-evoked measure of facial/social communication (gaze/eye contact perception). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Exclude. The analysis is a three-way Age group × evaluative perspective × domain ANOVA including adolescents and adults (not a healthy adult-only sample) and reports between-group interactions. The paper also reports ROI analyses of ventral striatum. Inclusion requires a whole-brain group-level univariate map generalizable to healthy adults and no between-group contrasts, so this analysis does not meet the criteria.

The contrast indexes neural responses to others' eye gaze (social attention perception) and correlations with AQ in typical adults. Although it is a whole-brain, group-level task analysis on healthy participants, it probes perception of others rather than Perception and Understanding of Self (self-awareness, self-traits, self-monitoring), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct.

Healthy adult sample (typical individuals), group-level voxelwise task analysis reporting whole-brain FDR-corrected correlations between AQ and the contrast (variable vs constant eye gaze). The task probes perception of others' social attention (eye gaze), and the analysis is not ROI-based, connectivity, or a between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (low-distress infant cry > pink noise), the task probes perception of infant emotional stimuli (auditory/social/emotion processing), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (low-distress infant cry > pink noise) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women), measuring perception of an auditory social cue (infant cries = reception of non‑facial social communication). This is a group-level, within-group whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing an attachment-relevant social stimulus (infant low-distress cries) to a non-social control (pink noise). This is a group-level task fMRI contrast (low-distress infant cry > pink noise) in healthy adult participants and indexes perception of another's emotional/vocal state (infant distress). The contrast compares pink noise to infant cries (perception of others' vocalizations), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or self-related judgments. This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants comparing infant cries (social/emotional vocalizations) to pink noise. Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women), group-level task fMRI contrast (High-distress infant cry > pink noise) reflecting perception of infant vocalizations (reception of non-facial social communication). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This contrast (high-distress infant cry > pink noise) probes auditory/social perception of infant cues in nulliparous women, not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or agency. The contrast (pink noise vs high-distress infant cry) indexes auditory/social processing of infant stimuli, not tasks or contrasts that probe perception/understanding of the self (agency or self-knowledge). This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants comparing infant cries (emotional social cues) to a nonsocial control (pink noise). Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women); group-level task-evoked whole-brain contrast (infant cry vs pink noise). This is a within-group, voxelwise task contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing auditory pink noise to infant cry stimuli. The contrast indexes perception of infant distress (low vs high cry) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or self-related judgment. This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (low- vs high-distress infant cries) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) indexing perception of others' emotional vocalizations (infant distress). This is a group-level, voxelwise task contrast (Sad face > Neutral face) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) measuring affective facial perception — i.e., reception of facial communication. Healthy adult sample (nulliparous women); group-level task-evoked whole-brain contrast (Sad face > Neutral face) assessing perception of others' emotional states (infant facial emotion), and not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast Sad Face > Happy Face reflects perception of emotional infant faces (others), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. The analysis is a group-level, voxelwise contrast (Low-distress infant cry > pink noise) in a healthy adult sample (nulliparous women) with brain activity correlated with BIS. Although this is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (high-distress infant cry > pink noise, correlated with BAS Drive) probes perception of infant stimuli and individual differences in motivational drive — not processes of perceiving or judging the self. This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) comparing infant cries to pink noise. Participants are healthy adults (nulliparous women). Sample = healthy adults (nulliparous women). This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) from a study including a clinical group (schizophrenia). This is a between-group contrast (Patients > Controls) involving a clinical sample (schizophrenia patients) rather than a within-group whole‑brain map from healthy adults. It therefore violates the sample requirement and the exclusion of between‑group contrasts.

This analysis refers to execution (production) of familiar gestures in a study of schizophrenia vs controls, not to perception/understanding of other people’s states or actions. It therefore does not target the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct (which emphasizes perceiving/inferring others), and the study involves a clinical group rather than a healthy-only group, so it fails the sample and construct inclusion criteria.
